message: How do I install TextMate?
How do I create a Sinatra app?
How do I create a GitHub account?
How do I fix a bug or add a feature to someone else's GitHub repo? (forking and pull requests)
How do I find a gem to do XXX?
What is rack?

I'm going to start doing a 5-minute "ruby newbie" segment at the start of each meetup where I go over a really basic bit of Ruby for the new members of the meetup. I'm looking for questions, so please look at the examples below and reply with your own. Since we don't want to bore more experienced members the questions should be able to be answered in 5 minutes or less, and should assume users can use the command-line but are new to Ruby.
How do I setup RVM?
How do I start a new Rails app?
How do I install vim?
How do I install gems with Bundler?

Most of the technical documentation can be found on how to install stuff (some of the RVM documentation is fantastic). I run into the problem of "Why would I use this thing? What are the advantages of using it?". A good example was the coffee script demo where it was like "this is why you should use coffee script, and here's some examples".
What is the difference between Sinatra and Rails?
What is RubyGems?
This is a great idea, but can we make sure to cover some theory on why we would use some of these things, like... "Why use RVM? Advantages of Textmate. What is a Sinatra app, and why would I use it?"

@RyanOnRails I'd also like to focus on writing wiki entries for basic topics (like RVM, bundler, vim, TextMate, Rack, etc.) which come up a lot with new developers. Then they've got somewhere we can point them for help.
@MarkBennett Ahhh, understood. Cool.

@RyanOnRails that's a good point, as sometimes knowing why to use a tool is just as important as how. I'm seeing these being really quick mini-talks, that probably answer popular questions from the previous meetup so hopefully the why will already be covered. If it was an important topic like RVM or bundler there may also be a longer talk to go with, as we've already done with RVM.
And @topgenorth is right; knowing the sweet spots for sinatra and rails would help a lot of people.

I think the sinatra app one is esp. nice. The code is usually tiny, benefits are immediately clear and should be fast to demo. In a way newer ruby devs might get more from sinatra first then step up to rails.
